DOCNAME: CASE OF ČADEK AND OTHERS v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
CONCLUSION: No violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Protection of property (Article 1 para. 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Peaceful enjoyment of possessions)
JUDGES: André Potocki;Angelika Nußberger;Dean Spielmann;Helena Jäderblom;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger
TEXT: CARDINAL . Under LAW , restitution claimants were entitled to restitutio in integrum of land which had been confiscated from them DATE . If it was not possible , for various reasons indicated in the LAW , to restore a particular plot of land , they were entitled to receive compensatory land of equivalent value ( “ restitution claim ” ) . ORG ( pozemkový fond ) , a public body under ORG ( hereinafter “ the Fund ” ) , deals with these restitution claims . Some original restitution claimants transferred their claims to other persons , a practice which was allowed by law . The restitution claims had a nominal value , which was based on the price of the confiscated land in DATE .

CARDINAL . Act no . CARDINAL amending LAW ( “ LAW ” ) was passed on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . It provided that if the ORG had not settled a claim for a substitute plot of land by DATE or within DATE if the claim had been purchased after entry into force of LAW the claim would be extinguished and the restitution claimant would retain only the right to financial compensation in the amount of the nominal value of the claim . By DATE many restitution claims were still outstanding .

CARDINAL . On DATE the board of directors of the ORG adopted a confidential internal directive in accordance with which the ORG would draw up contracts for the transfer of plots of land with persons who , like some of the applicants , had instituted proceedings against it . This practice was terminated on DATE . When the media discovered this DATE - long practice in DATE , they portrayed it as scheming with restitution claims within the ORG . According to them , those who had profited from it had been mostly people who had known about the directive and instituted proceedings after DATE , including some friends of managers of the ORG . As a result of the disclosure of this practice , CARDINAL managers of the Fund were dismissed and on DATE the Minister of Agriculture resigned . Subsequently , the ORG started to institute proceedings in order to have those transfer contracts rendered null and void .

CARDINAL . This Act provides , inter alia , for the restitution of certain agricultural and other properties , which were ceded or transferred to the ORG or other legal persons DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides that if the actual property can not be restored to its rightful owner , for example because the land has been built on , the ORG will transfer other equivalent ORG - owned property , preferably located in the same area , to the rightful claimant , if the latter consents .

CARDINAL . In accordance with section CARDINAL , if property can not be restored to its rightful owners and the latter can not be compensated by the transfer of other property to them , they have a right to financial compensation under certain conditions .
CARDINAL . NORP Under section CARDINALa , financial compensation is based on the value of the confiscated property on DATE , estimated in accordance with the regulations in force at that time .

CARDINAL . Act no . CARDINAL amending LAW ( “ LAW ” ) entered into force on DATE , having been approved by ORG on DATE . It provided that any right to the transfer of substitute plots of land by the ORG under LAW that had not been settled within DATE from the date the restitution claim had been established would be extinguished , and claimants would be entitled only to financial compensation under section CARDINALa . Concerning claims that were established before LAW entered into force , the right to substitute plots of land would be extinguished on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG repealed the time - limit introduced by LAW for settling the claims of the original restitution claimants by transferring a substitute plot of land on the basis that it breached LAW No . CARDINAL . It held that given that the ORG had not been effectively settling outstanding claims – it had not been offering enough plots of land for transfer and there had been no effective legal remedy for enforcing those claims – the time - limit in effect deprived restitution claimants of their claims , which constituted legitimate expectations under LAW No . CARDINAL . However , the court distinguished between original restitution claimants and persons who had acquired restitution claims from them by deed . It said that only the rights of the original restitution claimants had been breached , because the transferees must have been aware of the difficulties in settling restitution claims and of the risks that accompanied them , so they could not be said to have legitimate expectations .

CARDINAL . ORG , enlarging on the above decision of ORG , held that the time - limit for settling claims for substitute plots of land did not apply to farmers who needed the land for their own farming , even if they were not original restitution claimants . It held that the right to substitute plots of land constituted “ possessions ” under LAW No . CARDINAL and that LAW , which in practice had deprived farmers of this right , had not struck a fair balance between the competing interests . It distinguished between the situation of a farmer who needed the land for his or her own farming , which was in compliance with the object and purpose of LAW , and those dealing in property , whose commercial activities involved certain risks .

CARDINAL . In DATE and DATE ORG conducted an audit of the ORG and found , inter alia , several irregularities in the way in which it dealt with restitution claims . It noted that the ORG ’s offer of plots of land to settle restitution claims had been limited and that the ORG had favoured the sale of land before using it to settle the restitution claims . It found some further irregularities in the way in which the ownership of land had been transferred under LAW .
